Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Tractive Drive System Proof-of-Concept
Award.AbstractNarration: This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will revolutionize vertical transportation for skyscraper-class buildings (150 meters or taller). The skyscraper-class segment of the total addressable global elevator market is estimated at $8 billion for installation, driven by two key trends: urban densification and aging societies. It is expected that the number of people over 65 will increase by 33% by 2050 and that upwards of 70% of the world’s population will live in urban centers by the end of the century. This demographic shift will create an new demand for space in densely populated urban areas, skyscraper-class buildings within, and associatd vertical transportation systems.<br/><br/>The intellectual merit of this project is to develop a cable-less, tractive drive system to propel an elevator cab. Equipped with a tractive drive system, cabs become self-propelled, high-performance electric vehicles that are not bound to a single shaft, but instead navigate autonomously throughout multiple shafts. In addition, the absence of cables allows multiple cabs to travel within the same shaft, enabling greater transport capacity and shorter wait times to be achieved using fewer shafts. The tractive drive system propels cabs using frictional forces developed between the tractive drive wheels and the shaft. The objective of this Phase I project is to construct a proof-of-concept prototype that will allow for (1) direct measurement of the frictional behavior of the tractive drive wheel and shaft material combinations for the expected scale, geometries, and ambient operating conditions, and (2) verification that the expected mechanical performance (i.e., load-bearing capacity, power transmission) is achievable. This demonstrates the feasibility of such a system.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hyprlift, Inc. is seeking to develop and commercialize a novel vertical transportation system for the ever-denser urban centers of tomorrow. Consisting of multiple autonomous cabs circulating within a network of interconnected shafts, this system will overcome many limitations of conventional elevator technologies and deliver enhanced value propositions to developers and operators of skyscraper-class buildings. Hyprlift offers the ability to meet the vertical transportation needs of the world’s tallest structures while consuming far less core space than conventional cabled elevators.

The technical work for this Phase I project entailed the creation and validation of a proof-of-concept testbed platform for the tractive drive technology at the core of Hyprlift's system. Utilizing battery-operated, high-powered electric motors and custom-manufactured powertrains, the Hyprlift testbed platform (see the included image) was able to easily carry over 1000 lbs of payload (aside from its own 1700 lb weight) in its two-story excursions within Hyprlift’s laboratory space in Honolulu, Hawai’i. The kinematic, power, and thermal data gathered from this work has allowed Hyprlift to proceed to the next phase of its commercialization plan, including application for a more-extensive Phase II Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project. This project has also allowed Hyprlift to obtain a unique understanding of the complex surface interactions (and their resulting frictional forces) that make its propulsion technology possible, as well as real-world empirical data to better inform its designs and simulations.


Last Modified: 05/19/2022
Modified by: James B Hutchinson

Image
  • The Hyprlift SBIR Phase I testbed platform in its parked position, viewed from the electronics and payload shelving side of the device. The tractive drive system (behind the shelving) gripped the central rail (visible above and behind the shelving) to propel the platform.
    Hyprlift, Inc.
    James B Hutchinson
    Hyprlift, Inc. SBIR Phase I Testbed Platform
